and apartments but didn't know about this side of the city. I remember people calling me
"Seth" when I first visited Mumbai, I was like kaun main "Seth"? I came to the city on a flight,
travelled in taxis, ate in restaurants, and stayed in apartments or in a 4-star hotel, did my
research and projects and enjoyed it too. In the process, I had a cash crunch sometimes,
and I thought I was poor, how good it would be to be rich. :)
We are actually privileged, and whenever we feel disappointed about our lives, we should
see how people are making their living in the same city. Avoid spoiling yourself, guys! Value
what you have. Cheers!

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: A wonderful documentary! Though as a person from Mumbai, I do have some different view

comments.text:
points.
1) I noticed that majority houses in Dharavi had ACs in them. If you are rich enough to afford
ACs, why can you not at the least keep the place where you live clean??
2) Lets say the government does eradicate the slum and give the residents of Dharavi flats
under the redevelopment project, 99% of these people would sell those flats, come back to
these slums and live under these conditions like it happened in Delhi.
3) Also notice how majority of the women are wearing gold in the video. These people are
not as poor as we believe them to be. They voluntarily choose to live under such pathetic
situations. Being poor does not mean you have to live unhygienically.
They complain about the trash they themselves throw and the dirty conditions they
themselves create.

humaare poorvajo ko ye kya jagah pasand aai rehne ke liye mast kahi thandi hari bhari hill
station pe nahi bas sakte they? And my grandfather would always laugh and say this same
thing everytime "Beta apna ghar apna ghar hota hai"....years later when I went on a
looonnng trip covering major tourist places in India, at the end of the trip I was LITERALLY
DYING to get home and let me tell you THE MOMENT I entered Thar, I got it all and I
FINALLY understood why my grandfather said what he said! I am not at all emotional as a
person but I LITERALLY got so overwhelmed seeing APNA GHAR. Soooooo many pyaar
bhari feelings were there in our hearts for our home but all we said was....chalo bhayi
akhirkaar laut ke buddhu ghar ko aaye!

comments.timestamp: I'm from Thar in Pakistan. Here's what I noticed about the differences: We don't have wind

comments.text:
power generators or solar plants. There are no canals. I was born and raised in a village
where we stored rainwater, just as shown in the video. Once it's depleted, we switch back to
salty water, which contains a high amount of minerals such as calcium. No wonder I have
kidney stones. Economic opportunities are scarce. People make their living either from
farming or raising cattle, which is severely affected by a shortage of rain. To the people of
Thar, rain brings smiles. Water is sacred. It wasn't much developed until coal was
discovered, which brought lavish roads, economic opportunities, and media attention,
leading to a surge in tourism. The coal, which is currently fueling the local economy and
uplifting many from poverty, comes at the cost of the environment. The poverty-stricken
people have few choices. The flora and fauna we were once proud of, along with the clean
air, are now in question. For how long? Peace тЬМ

videos.title: I investigated IndiaтАЩs failed city of Rs 6,67,000 CRORES | Amaravati, Andhra PradeshThis Indian city was supposed to become the world's most sustainable city. Which looks like this today.
videos.transcript: Time: 00:00 - 00:10 This city has not just failed; today it lies barren. Modi: "Amaravati, with a new identity, is truly becoming the peopleтАЩs capital." Time: 00:10 - 00:20 24,000 farmers sacrificed their fertile land. Time: 00:20 - 00:30 To create India's most attractive capital city. Where there would be water taxis, and everything would run on solar power. But today, even the flyovers are not completed here. Time: 00:30 - 00:40 These electricity towers have been built here, but they don't even have wires yet. Government buildings are sitting empty. "They have even slapped 20 cases against me". Time: 00:40 - 00:50 20 cases against your name? So, you gave your land for development, and they filed cases against you? Time: 00:50 - 01:00 Look! Even the sewage work hasnтАЩt started yet. These large pipes were supposed to be installed inside. To create a proper drainage system, but they are still lying unaligned. Time: 01:00 - 01:10 This place was supposed to become the Singapore of India, but it doesnтАЩt seem so now. Time: 01:10 - 01:20 All because of the ego of an Indian politician. The richest Chief Minister in India today has committed the biggest scam with the people of this city. Time: 01:20 - 01:30 тАЬAndhra Pradesh is taking a significant step.тАЭ Time: 01:40 - 01:50 For this video, I will personally visit every corner of this city and talk to the locals. To experience and explain to you the dreams shown and the actual reality. Time: 01:50 - 02:00 We are just 46 minutes away from Amaravati. The temperature is 42 degrees but it feels like 52 degrees. Time: 02:00 - 02:10 "There are excessive heatwave warnings from the government's Meteorological Department." Time: 02:10 - 02:20 "We are dead." This is Amaravati, located within Andhra Pradesh. It was split 10 years ago, and thatтАЩs when the confusion about the capital started. Time: 02:20 - 02:30 Because when it split, Hyderabad was the capital of Andhra Pradesh. Which after the split, went to Telangana. Then, the CM of Andhra Pradesh chose Amaravati as the capital. Time: 02:30 - 02:40 At that time, no one knew this would become India's most complicated capital. All because of the ego of an Indian politician. To make this video, our entire team has worked in 50-degree Celsius heat, spending two whole days outside. Time: 02:40 - 02:50 So, this video definitely deserves your like. And be sure to watch the video till the end as you will find the solutions there. Time: 02:50 - 03:00 We barely found a room here. There are absolutely no accommodations available here. Didn't find? What happened? Time: 03:00 - 03:10 "These rooms are not functional". Found another one. Time: 03:10 - 03:20 "I'll go check it out." All the best. We ask around here. Let's see if it's here or not. Is anyone here? Time: 03:20 - 03:30 "Nope. No one here." Forget the hotel, the entire city is half-built. This barren- looking building behind me is the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly. Time: 03:30 - 03:40 It's an important building because all the state laws are made here. But today, this important building is situated amidst this barren land. Time: 03:40 - 03:50 When planned, it was said to be bigger than the world's tallest statue. Even bigger than the Statue of Unity. Time: 03:50 - 04:00 But today, only one floor has been built. "So why was this place chosen as the capital? What's so special about this place?" Time: 04:00 - 04:10 The reason is this one person, Chandrababu Naidu. When Andhra Pradesh was split, Naidu was the Chief Minister here. Naidu's vision was to create a greenfield capital city. Time: 04:10 - 04:20 What is a greenfield city? Let's understand it through toys. There should be some fun and excitement amidst serious educational content. Time: 04:20 - 04:30 A greenfield city is one that is built from scratch. On land where no development has taken place before. Amaravati is perfect for such a greenfield capital because. Time: 04:30 - 04:40 Why? I'll explain with maps. First, Amaravati is right in the center of the entire state. Second, it's exactly between two important urban centers. Time: 04:40 - 04:50 And third, there's an important river right next to Amaravati. Time: 04:50 - 05:00 The Krishna River. That's why there's always water available in this city. But the most important reason is these farms. Lots of fertile farms. Which were owned by farmers. Time: 05:00 - 05:10 Normally, clearing these farms requires many permissions. Farmers would have protested. But it didn't happen with Naidu because he had strong support from these farmers. Time: 05:10 - 05:20 Therefore, farmers from more than 20 villages, totaling 24,000. Donated their highly fertile land to build this capital city. Not just a little, but 28,000 acres of highly fertile land. Time: 05:20 - 05:30 ThatтАЩs more than the size of Chandigarh. This was the largest land donation made by farmers in India. Which gave this project a very good start. Time: 05:30 - 05:40 But these farmers didn't know that their fertile land would soon become barren. Just like their dreams. Time: 05:40 - 05:50 As soon as the land was acquired, Naidu started working quickly. He wanted to make it a peopleтАЩs capital that would be the most sustainable in the world. Just like Singapore. PM Modi came to lay the foundation of the city. Time: 05:50 - 06:00 This city was going to be huge. With lots of people and lots of employment. Time: 06:10 - 06:20 All electricity would come from solar panels. Water taxis were going to be built for transport. Five different types of roads were planned. Time: 06:20 - 06:30 One for pedestrians. One for public transport. And one for bicycles. The world's best Legislative building and High Court were going to be built. Time: 06:30 - 06:40 This city was going to have 9 districts. Each with its own specialty. One was going to be called the sports district, another the health district. Time: 06:40 - 06:50 And this entire city was going to have underground facilities. Time: 06:50 - 07:00 Of course, its cost was going to be very high. And for the first time in history, the government of Singapore worked directly with an Indian government. Time: 07:00 - 07:10 Other global investors also joined, such as the World Bank, the Asian Infrastructure Bank, and the Lulu Group. Time: 07:30 - 07:40 The city's plan was released in 2015, with the goal to complete it fully by 2024. Naidu even started a tour of Amaravati. Where people from around the world came to see the city's progress. Time: 07:40 - 07:50 But they didn't know that the city would stall after just the first phase. Because something was about to happen that Naidu had not imagined. Time: 07:50 - 08:00 News: "Chandrababu Naidu may resign from the CM post this evening." Naidu was shocked in the 2019 elections. His party, which used to rule 117 seats, got only 23 this time. Time: 08:00 - 08:10 This humiliating defeat was attributed to Jagan Mohan Reddy. Whose party won 151 seats. But he also became the villain of this entire story. Time: 08:10 - 08:20 He took Naidu's political power and shattered the dream of his city too. He clearly stated that he would not make Amaravati the capital and would stop construction there. Time: 08:30 - 08:40 Jagan didn't just reject Amaravati as the capital. He came up with a very odd plan. He said that for the first time in India, a state would not have one, not two, but three capitals. Time: 08:40 - 08:50 And they would be far apart. The legislative capital would be right in the middle of the state - Amaravati. The administrative capital would be on the coast - Visakhapatnam. Time: 08:50 - 09:00 And the judicial capital would be 700 km away - Kurnool. Coordinating this would be very difficult. And the logistics cost would be high. Jagan said this is how it's done in South Africa. Time: 09:00 - 09:10 Okay, it happens there. But we can't just copy a foreign example in India without considering the context. In India, Himachal Pradesh has two capitals, but they are winter and summer capitals. Time: 09:10 - 09:20 Because the temperatures there are extremely extreme. But that's not the case in Andhra Pradesh. I'm not saying Jagan and his party are completely wrong. Time: 09:20 - 09:30 But what happened in this case was wrong. Because now, the farmers of Amaravati had already donated their land. So why was there a need to propose having three separate capitals? Time: 09:30 - 09:40 Creating three separate capitals means acquiring more land. Which would cost money. Andhra Pradesh is already in debt of 3 lakh crore. Time: 09:40 - 09:50 It's among the top 10 highest debt states in India. Government employees' salaries are being delayed. So where will the money come from to acquire more land? What's the point of this fancy plan? Time: 09:50 - 10:00 Where 3 different places are made capitals. Especially when the development of Amaravati has been completely halted. Time: 10:00 - 10:10 They were supposed to build a modern high court but only half of it has been built. It was said there would be a helipad, but the nearest airport is an hour away. 12 buildings have been built for government officers, with 44 floors. Time: 10:10 - 10:20 But all of them are empty. The drainage pipes have not been installed. And foreign investors have also withdrawn their money. Time: 10:20 - 10:30 Those 30,000 farmers who gave their fertile land. Today, it lies completely barren. Their trust is broken, and they haven't received any money for their land. Time: 10:30 - 10:40 That's why those farmers have been protesting for years. This is the place where farmers have been protesting for years. The protest is currently paused because it's election time. Time: 10:40 - 10:50 The election code is in effect. But still, we have met some farmers and we will talk to them. "1600 days of protest have been ongoing." 1600 days of protest? Time: 10:50 - 11:00 How many people are protesting? "At least 25,000 people." "My family had given 16 acres of land for this capital." Was farming done on the 16 acres of land given? Time: 11:00 - 11:10 "Yes, 3-4 crops a year. First bananas, then gram, moong." Bananas, gram, moong. "I gave my land to the government, now there's nothing in my name". Time: 11:10 - 11:20 Farmers took this matter to the High Court. The High Court ordered Jagan to finish the city's development in 6 months. Time: 11:20 - 11:30 Jagan didn't do exactly that. But yes, he did withdraw his weird, fancy plan for 3 capital cities. And this case went to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court hasn't given a verdict yet. Time: 11:30 - 11:40 It said we will know what the new capital will be when the new government is formed in the 2024 elections. It's so wrong that a city's basic development depends on an election. Time: 11:40 - 11:50 This city lacks basic facilities like transport, drainage, electricity because the CM's ego is so big. Time: 11:50 - 12:00 Placing political power above people's needs is absolutely wrong. Which happens often in India. Not just here. It happened in the bullet train project as well. Time: 12:00 - 12:10 Which was stopped when the government changed. This also led to a lot of foreign investment loss. And because of this whole political ego game, no new city has been built from scratch in India for many years. Time: 12:10 - 12:20 All the burden is on a few big cities. It's not like we don't have small cities. They have a lot of potential to develop. Time: 12:20 - 12:30 What's needed is political will. My aim on YouTube is to make a video on every district in India. Time: 12:30 - 12:40 So please leave information about your district in the comments. Who knows, the next video might be on that. And subscribe, to your mate, KK Create. Bye! Time: 12:40 - 12:50Amazing video, Kavya! є░Ч▒
